code:
export default { introData: [{ title: "What this is", text: `

Just a couple quick things, and you really only need to read this 1st slide for context . This is NOT so much a resumé as it is a portfolio. I just decided to use my 24 years of experience as the primary source of data (all from a single JSON object ), and I do not expect anyone to actually read any of this. Your goal here is to get a feel for what I CAN do, moreso than what I have done , and the target audience is someone that understands Web Development .

This is an example of what I can do in about 1 week's time . Call it a personal coding challenge, or better yet, my digital playground. Just be aware that it may be a bit "rough around the edges" for a short time. If you simply want my professional history, go to my LinkedIn profile . You can also get a copy of my single page resumé here.

If you'd like more context, like why I did this, the approach I took, the tools & resources I used, what I plan on doing next with this, etc... click "Next". And for your convenience, I created (invented?) a brevity feature to spare you from the filler words that some may find annoying.

Otherwise, just close this minor annoyance and peruse away. BTW, there are 2 themes currently. One is very basic, and the other looks like Nicki Minaj and Office Max had a baby . Use the theme link in the menu to toggle between them. Thanks!

` }, { title: "What to expect", text: `

Imperfection & Change... a disclaimer of sorts.

This is not your traditional portfolio . Much of my last several years of work has been focussed on internal or subscription-based web applications vs public-facing sites.

Again, the bulk of this was done in 1 week . My focus was speed, and therefore there is quite a bit of refining to be done . I just wanted to get something recent and representative of my skillset up and running quickly. I'm also integrating feedback and adding features as they come to me. If it seems that I've ignored any particular aspect i.e: W3C validation, WCAG compliance, browser coverage, device coverage, more Intuitivityness(sm)... this will have all of those. It's currently just a prototype and not what I would consider production quality.

At this point, and with exception to a few minor bugs, everything should be pretty solid when viewed on desktop or laptop using any recent browser not made by Microsoft, and I'm about 80% there for tablets and phones . I intend for this to be available for large screens as well.

` }, { title: "Why I made this", text: `

Aside from coding challenges, I've had no need for a "portfolio" for over 8 years now. And that dusty old portfolio was tucked safely away on a CD, in a non-descript box, mixed in with many other boxes waiting to be dealt with some day - one day. I also certainly would never keep any IP for myself that rightfully belongs to anyone paying me to invent & produce it. I should also add that the highest value I can bring to a project is nothing that can be gazed upon . But according to every non-developer individual I speak to lately, it would seem I require something to look at. (I wonder if LinkedIn is aware of how useless they've become.) This would be great read in Morgan Freeman's voice BTW.

That all said, sure, I'll take screenshots every now and again and email them to myself. You see, Gmail has been my primary storage provider since... well, forever. And there was a time when I had screenshots as recent as about 6 months ago ... until Google informed me that I was running out of space .

What could possibly go wrong if I were to quickly free up space by deleting every email attachment I've ever received that was over 1MB in size? Actually, I'm not that careless. I carefully sifted through everything prior to said deletion and backed the important items up to a usb thumb drive .

Cut to December 2019 and a disasterous, overly time consuming, 2012 Macbook upgrade to Catalina. I needed a bootable usb drive STAT to bring this ordeal to a speedy end.

Now I know what you're thinking... That's a bit unfortunate, but he did do it to himself. You're probably also thinking: IF we hire this guy, he is NOT allowed to write documentation!!!

` }, { title: "How I made this", text: `

Zero planning whatsoever (Not recommended). And BTW, thank you for reading on this far! I totally would have stopped after the first section and started sniffing around in the browser source. Continuing on...

How to (generally) prepare for a project:

  1. Define existing problem(s), barrier(s), bottleneck(s), missing piece(s)...
  2. Establish the need(s), value(s), audience(s), and combinations therein.
  3. Determine core features and set project scope & constraints.
  4. Wireframe & Prototype.
  5. Lock down a definition of done, environment(s), testing, integration, metrics...
  6. Define intervals for assessing progress and possible changes.
  7. GO!
  8. ** And don't work on it for ~14 hours per day, every day, until "done".

Yeah, I didn't do any of that , except for the last 2. And I so nailed it! Seriously, it's been a lot of fun, but I should have self-imposed at least a few additional best practices , even though it was a rushed pet/personal project. I certainly will be, going forward. But all things considered, I knocked out a pretty substantial prototype in a week . And if that's something you need, I'm definitely the person for that .

The next section will detail the craft, tech & tools used or ignored. Frameworks, APIs, standards, that sort of thing.

` }, { title: "What I used", text: `

When knocking out a rapid prototype, some things are instinctive, like a semantic use of markup or jQuery for roughing out more dynamic aspects. Other things like WCAG compliance or using the required flavor or JS framework are easily integrated later. Here are lists of what I did and didn't inplement, and additional indicators among the "didn't" list, that I WILL BE doing.

Used/applied:

  • Sublime Text
  • Semantic Markup
  • Responsive Design
  • Sloppy jQuery & vanilla JS
  • Haphazzard Theming
  • SCSS & Scout App
  • JSON
  • FontAwesome
  • Google Fonts & Maps APIs
  • Handlebars Templating
  • VUE.js, sort of
  • Moment
  • Modernizr
  • Flickity.js
  • NPM
  • Cloud Services
  • Brave Browser
  • Pixelmator Pro
  • Macbook
  • Pixel 3 XL
  • iPad
  • Maybe a couple copyrighted images
  • A few blatant hacks
  • BulletProof Coffee
  • Humorous Commenting

Not (yet) used/applied:

  • W3C & WCAG
  • UI/UX Design Patterns
  • Optimized JS
  • React.js
  • CSS ZenGarden-Level Theming
  • More Themes!
  • Ionic Mobile Framework
  • No Hacks!
  • Got a suggestion?
` }, { title: "What's next", text: `

SUCCESS!!!...(?) Cleanup. You have or will soon notice that many aspects of this are in an 80% done state. There's incomplete or missing content, some of the font and color choices are questionable, and several aspects of positioning and interaction need more attention. So here's the TODO list:

  1. Highly encourage, gratefully accept, and consider any and all feedback .
  2. Lock this down in its current prototypical state and publish all further development to a new subdomain . After all, you can't have a "before & after" if there's no before available.
  3. Add Google Analytics, metrics and event tracking to the "before" protoytpe to aid in the refinement of the "after".
  4. Evaluate interactive aspects, consistency, and adjust accordingly.
  5. Add W3C and WCAG compliance.
  6. Refine font and color choices for both themes.
  7. Simplify and clean up the CSS & JS, including any swearing in the comments.
  8. Ensure I'm not infringing on anyone's IP.
  9. Fill in all content blanks and check speeling.
  10. Test theming by adding a new one (requests?)
  11. Add more easter eggs. Did you find them all?
  12. Port this to Semantic-UI/React .
  13. Port THAT to Ionic for mobile apps . Because why not?
` }, { title: "Lessons learned", text: `

"That's nice, a full version of your resumé, but could you please provide a portfolio?"

This introduction that you are currently reading was not yet created on the day I first started directing people here, when asked for a portfolio. Above is a direct quote from a recruiter that was essentially echoed by a few more. A couple of friends simply asked me "What am I looking at again?"

"Context is ev-er-y-thing" has been my #1 personal mantra since before my last 24 years of development. When I was a surgical assistant, if I didn't know exactly what to do, when I had to do it, there could be grave circumstances. I started as a human surgical UI, and have since translated that skill to the interfaces I produce. And while I'm very good at being context aware, I'm certainly not perfect .

In my rush to get this together, I never saw it as anything other than a portfolio. But clearly that wasn't the case for anyone that couldn't read my mind. I should have stepped back at some point, or better yet, assembled a rough plan before going at it . That's my takeaway here. And I'm grateful that this UI has yet to injure or kill anyone ... yet.

Oh, and I may have gone a bit too crazy with the shadows and animations. I should tone that down a bit.

` }, { title: "Bonus", text: `

Why would I hire me?

For starters, I've clearly mastered brevity . Or at least I wrote a method to handle that for me.

I'm also JEFFREY. Judicious, Easy, Fast, Focussed, Ready, Eloquent, and Youthful... but in a good way.

... Still working on this, but enjoy that last paragraph while it lasts! ...

` }] };

export default { introData: [ { title: "What this is", text: `

Just a couple quick things, and you really only need to read this 1st slide for context . This is NOT so much a resumé as it is a portfolio. I just decided to use my 24 years of experience as the primary source of data (all from a single JSON object ), and I do not expect anyone to actually read any of this. Your goal here is to get a feel for what I CAN do, moreso than what I have done , and the target audience is someone that understands Web Development .

This is an example of what I can do in about 1 week's time . Call it a personal coding challenge, or better yet, my digital playground. Just be aware that it may be a bit "rough around the edges" for a short time. If you simply want my professional history, go to my LinkedIn profile . If you'd like more context, like why I did this, the approach I took, the tools & resources I used, what I plan on doing next with this, etc... click "Next". And for your convenience, I created (invented?) a brevity feature to spare you from the filler words that some may find annoying.

Otherwise, just close this minor annoyance and peruse away. BTW, there are 2 themes currently. One is very basic, and the other looks like Nicki Minaj and Office Max had a baby . Use the theme link in the menu to toggle between them. Thanks!

` }, { title: "What to expect", text: `

Imperfection & Change... a disclaimer of sorts.

This is not your traditional portfolio . Much of my last several years of work has been focussed on internal or subscription-based web applications vs public-facing sites.

Again, the bulk of this was done in 1 week . My focus was speed, and therefore there is quite a bit of refining to be done . At this point, and with exception to a few minor bugs, everything should be pretty solid when viewed on desktop or laptop using any recent browser not made by Microsoft, and I'm about 80% there for tablets and phones . I intend for this to be available for large screens as well.

Yeah, I didn't do any of that , except for the last 2. And I so nailed it! ` }, { title: "What I used", text: `

  • Responsive Design

` }, { title: "What's next", text: `

SUCCESS!!!...(?) Cleanup. You have or will soon notice that many aspects of this are in an 80% done state. There's incomplete or missing content, some of the font and color choices are questionable, and several aspects of positioning and interaction need more attention. So here's the TODO list:

Oh, and I may have gone a bit too crazy with the shadows and animations. I should tone that down a bit.

For starters, I've clearly mastered brevity . Or at least I wrote a method to handle that for me.
